results.title: Hit the ground running: making the leap from primary to secondary school
results.creator_credit: Video Education Australia, Robyn Holdsworth and Richard Leigh
results.brief_description: Research into the middle years of schooling has identified primary to secondary transition as a key period of risk in a young person’s education. A poor transition experience can manifest in a number of ways including truancy, behavioural and social problems, and disengagement from school. This video education kit builds on established practices for developing resiliency in young people. A range of specific strategies related to organisation, problem solving, conflict resolution and managing friendships are described and students are given the opportunity to practice these skills using a variety of scenarios. The video package is divided into four modules- 1. Secondary school: finding your way 2. problem solving 3. friends and pressure 4.conflict resolution. Comprehensive support material with suggested activities is also provided. Educational advisor, Marian Orr.

results.title: Hit and miss
results.brief_description: Presents nine vignettes about conflict between young people and their parents. Each situation tends to be sympathetic to young people. Focuses on typically Anglo-saxon family situations.

results.title: Hit
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Harry Korshak and Sidney J. Furie
results.brief_description: A special ‘hit’ team, consisting of 7 individuals are recruited for a death defying mission of revenge. Each has their own motivation for blood lust. They are led by a vigilante federal agent Nick Allen, played by Billy Dee Williams, who is motivated by seeking revenge against drug dealers for the death of his daughter. The location is Marseilles as they close in on the drug syndicate. Also starring Richard Pryor, Paul Hampton and Gwen Welles.

results.title: History on the run: the media and the '79 election
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Peter Raymont and Simon Riley
results.brief_description: History on the Run examines the media’s coverage of Canada’s federal election of May, 1979. Spanning a three-week period, it is literally filmed “on the run.” A fascinating look at journalists in action, it is also an opportunity to glimpse political figures behind the scenes and their attempts to manipulate the media.

results.title: History of man: how man discovers his past
results.creator_credit: McGraw-Hill Films, American Broadcasting Company and Gene Feldman
results.brief_description: Portrays the ways in which history is reconstructed by anthropologists, archaeologists, historians and others who investigate the past. Presents history as a process of reinterpretation, always subject to new evidence. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: History of football. Ep. 6
results.creator_credit: Fremantle International, Dario Pleic, Hereward Pelling and Guy Oliver
results.brief_description: Episode 6 of The History of football - or soccer as it is known in Australia. “Africa” From colonial intervention, poverty and segregation, to independence and dictatorship, this program examines Africa’s huge potential to become a successful football nation, against its continued failure to succeed at an international level. Including historical footage of key matches as well a slew of interviews with historians and sportsmen, this examination of the history of football in Africa makes for fascinating viewing. Interviews include: Roger Milla, Abedi Pele, Thomas N’kono, Neil Tovey, Pierre Kalala and Issa Hayatou. “A game for all” This episode focuses on the history of FIFA and the other powerbrokers that influence the spread of the game culturally as well as commercially, whilst documenting the start of football’s partnership with large multi-national corporations. Touches on the history of women and football with wonderful excerpt footage. Interviews include Joao Havelange, Lennart Johansson, Pele, Jack Warner, Charles Dempsey and Dwight Yorkes. “Futures” As football is still dominated by Europe and South America this episode questions where future challenges will come from at a time when soccer has gained in popularity in China, Korea, Japan, India and the Middle East. Utilising interviews and archival footage, this episode examines the impact of soccer on these nations and the machinations of popularising the sport. Interviews include Zico, Kazu Miura, Baichung Bhutia, Kunishige, Kamamoto and Hong Deok-young.
